quotes.topic_title: Markets as currents, not bodies of water
quotes.text: I actually think that the most interesting markets, you have to think of them like currents where you're there's something happening in the market that's creating this current where you can have a plank of wood that you've put on the river and it's going to pull you forward.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Introduces a memorable mental model for evaluating markets based on momentum rather than static size.

quotes.topic_title: Markets as currents, not bodies of water
quotes.text: Versus a market that doesn't really have that momentum to it, you're going to have to build something really big and fancy to make any progress.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Highlights the practical implication that lack of market pull forces founders to rely on heavier product/marketing effort to grow.

quotes.topic_title: Markets as currents, not bodies of water
quotes.text: That's why we care less about market size because really, what you're looking for when you're looking at a market, are what are the dynamics of change, what's the current and momentum that's going to pull the company and make the job easier for the founders to actually build something that endures.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Gives actionable guidance on market selection: prioritize change dynamics and momentum over TAM to increase odds of building an enduring company.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And though I normally have a policy against VCs on the podcast, as you'll see, Sarah thinks very much like a product and growth leader.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian selection principle: prioritize operator-grade thinking over a guest’s job title when seeking practical product/growth insights.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: In our conversation, we unpack two of Sarah's killer frameworks for building a startup.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals that the episode will be organized around reusable frameworks rather than anecdotes, useful for practitioners looking for repeatable methods.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: One, the hierarchy of engagement, which is an incredibly useful lens for trying to figure out how to grow and scale your consumer startup.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a named mental model (“hierarchy of engagement”) positioned as a practical tool for diagnosing and driving consumer growth.

quotes.topic_title: Introduction and Background
quotes.text: And then, the hierarchy of marketplaces, which is an incredibly useful guide for helping you build your marketplace startup.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Introduces a second named framework (“hierarchy of marketplaces”) aimed at guiding marketplace construction and scaling decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: In our conversation, we unpack two of Sarah's killer frameworks for building a startup.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Highlights that the episode will focus on practical, reusable frameworks for startup building.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: One, the hierarchy of engagement, which is an incredibly useful lens for trying to figure out how to grow and scale your consumer startup.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Introduces a specific growth framework practitioners can apply to consumer startup scaling.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: And then, the hierarchy of marketplaces, which is an incredibly useful guide for helping you build your marketplace startup.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Introduces a second framework aimed at marketplace design and execution.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: Why choose Gelt? Because they offer year-round proactive tax planning, and clear, fast communication.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Actionable service criteria: prioritize proactive planning and fast communication when selecting a tax partner.

quotes.topic_title: Sponsor Break
quotes.text: People working at companies such as Notion, Google and Lip have already experienced the Gelt difference.
quotes.speaker: Host
quotes.context: Provides concrete examples of recognizable companies used as social proof for the service.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sarah is the VC exception
quotes.text: So you may or may not know this, but actually, normally have a policy of no VCs on the podcast.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A contrarian stance that sets up a deliberate filter for whose advice is worth platforming—and why exceptions matter.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sarah is the VC exception
quotes.text: But you're a very special VC because you're a former product manager.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practitioner-first lens: product experience as a differentiator for actionable company-building guidance.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sarah is the VC exception
quotes.text: Many people don't know you were the first product manager at Pinterest.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A concrete credential/example grounding why her frameworks may be rooted in real operating experience.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sarah is the VC exception
quotes.text: What I want to do with our time together is dig into two frameworks that you've developed and use with founders that you work with to help them build successful companies.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Signals the practical intent: reusable frameworks explicitly designed for founders to apply.

quotes.topic_title: Why Sarah is the VC exception
quotes.text: One is focused around customer businesses, and one marketplace businesses.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A clear taxonomy that implies different playbooks depending on business model—useful for choosing the right strategy lens.

quotes.topic_title: Hierarchy of engagement: core action over vanity metrics
quotes.text: I think one thing you'll notice about me is that I have an allergic reaction to vanity metrics, what people talk about as vanity metrics.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A memorable stance that frames the framework around avoiding misleading growth indicators.

quotes.topic_title: Hierarchy of engagement: core action over vanity metrics
quotes.text: It felt to me like it wasn't obvious that those metrics that they were all getting very attached, and focused on, and showing in these presentations was the wrong thing to focus on.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Challenges the default founder habit of optimizing what’s easiest to chart rather than what predicts durable engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Hierarchy of engagement: core action over vanity metrics
quotes.text: What you realize when you look at social products is that they're almost is this action which I call the core action of that product that forms the foundation of the product.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Introduces the key mental model: define the product’s “core action” as the base layer of engagement.

quotes.topic_title: Hierarchy of engagement: core action over vanity metrics
quotes.text: When a user completes this action, it's clear that they both understand the utility of the product, they understand what that product is all about, and it's an action that, if they perform the action, they're very likely to come back.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Gives a practical criterion for choosing a core action: it signals comprehension and predicts retention.

quotes.topic_title: Hierarchy of engagement: core action over vanity metrics
quotes.text: So for Facebook, the obvious action is friending, in the beginning days. For Pinterest, it's pinning. I don't know if you're an Evernote user. For Evernote, it's writing a note.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Concrete examples that help practitioners identify analogous core actions in their own products.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right core action and NUX
quotes.text: By the way, this action, it's very important to pick the right action. You want to make sure it's an action that scales to enough users. You want to think about, "If I think about my product roadmap and optimize for it, what do we end up doing?"
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A practical criterion for choosing a core action: it must scale and it will shape what your roadmap becomes.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right core action and NUX
quotes.text: Just to give you a more concrete example, actually in the early days of Pinterest, we weren't sure what it was. We had all these things we were measuring. We were measuring follows, we were measuring clicking through, liking something, pinning obviously, time on site. We would do these experiments and you would get all this different data where some things would go up, some things would go down. What were we optimizing for?
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A specific example of how unclear core metrics create noisy experiment results and confusion about what to optimize.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right core action and NUX
quotes.text: There's something that's really, really important about having that clarity of this is the action that is most important for our product. All things, our NUX has to lead to this. If a user isn't doing this, then there's something missing from their experience of the product. It's super important to get real clarity and know exactly the one that you're going to be picking to go forward.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A clear framework: define the single most important action and design the entire new user experience to drive it.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right core action and NUX
quotes.text: To me, it is are you taking those new users and helping them understand the mental model of your product well enough that they start completing the core action.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A concrete way to measure NUX success: whether it teaches the product’s mental model enough to trigger the core action.

quotes.topic_title: Choosing the right core action and NUX
quotes.text: There was a NUCs once that we played with at Pinterest where we didn't even teach people what pinning was. It was their feed magically appeared and it was a real ... That was an example of okay, we have to help people understand that they are here to discover something and save it to their board.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A cautionary example showing that a “magical” feed without teaching the core action can undermine activation.

quotes.topic_title: Level two: retention via accruing value
quotes.text: The test for me, of whether you're building a product that has the ingredients to create a retentive product on a micro level, just at the user level, is that the product should get better the more you use it, and you'll have more to lose by leaving it.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A crisp retention test practitioners can use to evaluate whether their product accrues user-specific value over time.

quotes.topic_title: Level two: retention via accruing value
quotes.text: It was this experience that, the more you pinned, the more personalized your home feed got for you.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A concrete example of using the core action (pinning) to directly improve the product experience via personalization.

quotes.topic_title: Level two: retention via accruing value
quotes.text: So you wouldn't abandon Pinterest because Pinterest was this repository for these different expressions of your identity, or these different bookmarks that you wanted to back to.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Explains the “more to lose by leaving” mechanism: accumulated identity and saved intent create switching costs and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Level two: retention via accruing value
quotes.text: What I means is that, the more I use it ... Now I know that I can do a search in my Evernote and I'm going to find the document I'm looking for. Now, I can never leave Evernote. It has everything. I have thousands and thousands of documents in Evernote.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Illustrates retention via accruing value: repeated use builds a trusted repository that becomes hard to replace.

quotes.topic_title: Level two: retention via accruing value
quotes.text: I love to think of every time a user users your product, let's say they're clicking on the mouse or they're tapping on their phone, I love to think of it as this kinetic energy that they're putting into your product. You're taking that energy, and your job with a great product, is to take that energy and, as much as possible, convert it back to the experience that they're having with your product.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for designing loops where user effort is converted into improved future experience and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Level three: self-perpetuating loops and network effects
quotes.text: Then, your tall task, and this is the hardest thing to overcome, is how do you make the product self-perpetuating? This is where I love to think of every time a user users your product, let's say they're clicking on the mouse or they're tapping on their phone, I love to think of it as this kinetic energy that they're putting into your product. You're taking that energy, and your job with a great product, is to take that energy and, as much as possible, convert it back to the experience that they're having with your product.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for designing products that convert user activity into compounding value and retention.

quotes.topic_title: Level three: self-perpetuating loops and network effects
quotes.text: Now, the biggest thing that you can do is a network effect. The more I pin something on Pinterest, the better the experience for every user on Pinterest. Every time I add a pin to a board, I'm creating a new edge in Pinterest Graph, that Pinterest then uses to create recommendations and enrich their understanding of all those objects on Pinterest.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A concrete example of how user actions create graph edges that directly improve recommendations for everyone.

quotes.topic_title: Level three: self-perpetuating loops and network effects
quotes.text: But, there's other loops too, that you have to identify and then maximize. These are the growth and re-engagement loops. These are classic loops, you talk about these a lot, they exist in marketplaces and social products. How do you get it so that, as your users use the product, they want to share it with other people? They create metadata that you can then use for SEO. You have collaborative experiences that pull other people in.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A practitioner-oriented checklist of non-network-effect loops (sharing, SEO metadata, collaboration) to engineer for growth and reactivation.

quotes.topic_title: Level three: self-perpetuating loops and network effects
quotes.text: Now, if you were a dormant user at that point, it's been a couple weeks since you'd used Pinterest, that notification might pull you back into Pinterest and be like, "Hey, I wonder what other pins Sarah has on her art board." It's a great re-engagement loop where Pinterest doesn't have to do anything there intentional. The user is creating the action that drives the outcome that Pinterest wants in that example.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Illustrates a self-driven re-engagement loop where user behavior triggers reactivation without extra company effort.

quotes.topic_title: Level three: self-perpetuating loops and network effects
quotes.text: What was interesting about both of those products is that you would think that the more users that came into Clubhouse or Houseparty, the faster the flywheel should spin. But the challenge was that they relied on push notifications. I don't know if you had this experience, but let's take Houseparty as an example. You started to follow a lot of people on Houseparty, and then all of a sudden, your push notifications just got overwhelming. Because it was a realtime product, that you had to use push noti cations to know the moment to join the product, but when you had so many push notifications because the more people you followed, the more notifications you had, you just get to this point where you start ignoring them. It becomes this thing where, even though the flywheel should be spinning faster, it starts breaking down.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A counterintuitive failure mode where scaling users increases notification overload and weakens (rather than strengthens) the engagement flywheel.

quotes.topic_title: When flywheels break: push notifications and overload
quotes.text: But the challenge was that they relied on push notifications.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Highlights a specific growth dependency that can become a bottleneck as a product scales.

quotes.topic_title: When flywheels break: push notifications and overload
quotes.text: Because it was a realtime product, that you had to use push noti cations to know the moment to join the product, but when you had so many push notifications because the more people you followed, the more notifications you had, you just get to this point where you start ignoring them.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Explains the mechanism by which engagement loops can degrade: scaling increases notifications until users tune them out.

quotes.topic_title: When flywheels break: push notifications and overload
quotes.text: It becomes this thing where, even though the flywheel should be spinning faster, it starts breaking down.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A counterintuitive observation that more users can slow growth when re-engagement triggers overload.

quotes.topic_title: When flywheels break: push notifications and overload
quotes.text: The importance of it is I can't emphasize enough how important focus is when you're building these companies.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Actionable advice to prioritize focus as a core operating principle during company building.

quotes.topic_title: When flywheels break: push notifications and overload
quotes.text: But there are these first principles of the ingredients that they all share, and you can use those ingredients to really focus you when you're going through the inevitable growth curve and wanting to know, "Well, how do we maximize this moment? How do we really focus on the things that will set us most up for success?"
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Describes a practical methodology: use shared first-principles “ingredients” as a focusing tool during growth inflection points.

quotes.topic_title: Why organic growth matters and TikTok’s spend
quotes.text: The importance of it is I can't emphasize enough how important focus is when you're building these companies.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Emphasizes focus as a core execution advantage when building consumer companies without a clear playbook.

quotes.topic_title: Why organic growth matters and TikTok’s spend
quotes.text: But there are these first principles of the ingredients that they all share, and you can use those ingredients to really focus you when you're going through the inevitable growth curve and wanting to know, "Well, how do we maximize this moment? How do we really focus on the things that will set us most up for success?"
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Introduces a first-principles “ingredients” lens as a practical framework for prioritization during growth inflection points.

quotes.topic_title: Why organic growth matters and TikTok’s spend
quotes.text: There's one example that we have so far, which is TikTok, of spending more than $1 billion, once they figured out actually the first two levels in order to grow.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Provides a concrete data point showing how even breakout winners may require massive spend after nailing retention and early growth mechanics.

quotes.topic_title: Why organic growth matters and TikTok’s spend
quotes.text: They didn't actually put user acquisition spend behind TikTok until they had a product that was retentive, and then they know that they really wanted to maximize that.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive sequencing advice: delay paid acquisition until retention is proven, then use spend to scale what already works.

quotes.topic_title: Why organic growth matters and TikTok’s spend
quotes.text: That just shows you how hard it is to break in and become a new social network, essentially, or a new social app.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights the competitive reality that displacing entrenched social incumbents is extraordinarily difficult even with large budgets.

quotes.topic_title: Fast growth, fast collapse and anonymity pitfalls
quotes.text: Most apps have this destructive K-factor that kicks in, the same way it kicked in to get it to spread.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: A memorable mental model: the same virality that drives rapid growth can also accelerate rapid collapse when activity drops.

quotes.topic_title: Fast growth, fast collapse and anonymity pitfalls
quotes.text: As people say, when something grows really quickly, it also can collapse really quickly.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A concise warning for practitioners to design for durability, not just acquisition, when growth spikes.

quotes.topic_title: Fast growth, fast collapse and anonymity pitfalls
quotes.text: Pseudo-anonymity and anonymity are very different concepts.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Sets up a practical distinction product teams can use when deciding whether identity should be persistent or fully anonymous.

quotes.topic_title: Fast growth, fast collapse and anonymity pitfalls
quotes.text: The challenge when you have pure anonymity is that you don't have that accruing benefit or mounting loss that happens.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Explains why retention and network effects often fail under pure anonymity: users lack incentives to invest in an identity they can’t build.

quotes.topic_title: Fast growth, fast collapse and anonymity pitfalls
quotes.text: I find anonymity, people keep trying it, and super talented founders keep hitting their head against that wall because it has the very early fun growth, but it just continues to be a product that isn't able to persist without some persistent identity.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive product lesson: anonymity can boost early growth but undermines long-term community health and persistence without identity.

quotes.topic_title: Retention basics: cohort measurement and geographic focus
quotes.text: Number one is actually measuring it. I can't tell you how many times I suggest to a founder to track cohorts and that's a new thing. Just being really, really clear and intellectually honest on looking at cohorts I think is number one.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Emphasizes that many teams still don’t measure retention properly, and that cohort tracking is the first practical step to improving it.

quotes.topic_title: Retention basics: cohort measurement and geographic focus
quotes.text: A cohort, what I always like to look at is weekly cohorts for these products.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Gives a concrete methodology choice—weekly cohorts—as the default unit for retention analysis in consumer products.

quotes.topic_title: Retention basics: cohort measurement and geographic focus
quotes.text: And I particularly love to look at that on a weekly active user completing the core action pieces of like, are users completing the core action?
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Adds a more diagnostic retention metric: not just activity, but weekly active users who complete the product’s core action.

quotes.topic_title: Retention basics: cohort measurement and geographic focus
quotes.text: And until you reach a point with your cohorts where there is a plateau, you have more work to do on figuring out the retention of your users.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Provides a clear heuristic for “good enough” retention: cohorts should flatten (plateau) rather than keep declining.

quotes.topic_title: Retention basics: cohort measurement and geographic focus
quotes.text: There was one example I saw, it was a kind of a dating app, friend making app, and he was growing it via TikTok, which is not geographically constrained at all. And so, he's growing the user numbers, but without focusing on a specific geography, it's gonna be really difficult to make that type of product a high retention product.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive growth lesson: broad top-of-funnel acquisition can hurt retention for geo/liquidity-dependent products if you don’t focus geographically.

quotes.topic_title: Most common mistake: unfocused level-one experience
quotes.text: But what that ends up meaning when the when a new user signs up is that there's too much in the beginning to to take in and understand, and you don't then have a very focused product that gets the user to the thing that you most want them to do.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Highlights the common failure mode of overbuilding early UX, which prevents users from reaching the core action quickly.

quotes.topic_title: Most common mistake: unfocused level-one experience
quotes.text: And that's actually part of the importance of understanding level one, what your core action is, is that you want to make sure that when a user comes to your product, signs up for the first time, doesn't have necessarily a lot of contacts on what the product is itself, that they see the thing that they're supposed to do and you get them to do it.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Defines a practical level-one focus: make the first-time experience drive users directly to the intended core action.

quotes.topic_title: Most common mistake: unfocused level-one experience
quotes.text: And a lot of times, in the beginning, there are just so many other things that a product might have that you're defusing that attention that they would otherwise have had on the on the thing that's most important.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A counterintuitive warning that adding features early can reduce activation by scattering user attention.

quotes.topic_title: Most common mistake: unfocused level-one experience
quotes.text: And so, I feel that that's the first mistake, and it's kind of natural that it would be the first mistake, but maybe the largest mistake that I see people make.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Emphasizes that unfocused early experience is not just common but the biggest mistake founders make.

quotes.topic_title: How Pinterest found its North Star metric
quotes.text: And what happened actually is that there was two efforts that I think of as like kind of bottoms-up and top-down that helped really clarify that, actually, pinning something was the core action, it was going to be our North Star.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Introduces a practical two-pronged methodology (bottoms-up + top-down) for identifying a product’s North Star metric.

quotes.topic_title: How Pinterest found its North Star metric
quotes.text: And the two things were, there's always this like bottoms-up analysis that you do, which is, we looked at every action that you could do on Pinterest, so we had liking, following, clicking through, time on site, pinning, repinning. And we looked at, first of all, what percentage of users complete those actions? And if you do that action in a week, what's your propensity to come back the following week? And we basically ranked that.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Gives a concrete, repeatable analysis approach: enumerate actions, measure completion rate and next-week return propensity, then rank.

quotes.topic_title: How Pinterest found its North Star metric
quotes.text: And what we saw was that if you pinned something, repinned something, which is finding something on Pinterest, I'm using those synonymously, or click through, you had an incredibly high probability that you would come back. So if someone's pinning something, they're coming back to Pinterest the next week with a super high, more than 90% probability at the time.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Provides a specific data point tying a candidate core action (pinning) to retention, supporting causality for a North Star metric.

quotes.topic_title: How Pinterest found its North Star metric
quotes.text: And then there's like the top-down way of thinking about it, which is, well, what is Pinterest for? And if a user does come to Pinterest and they never add something to a board, do they really understand what Pinterest is?
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Shows the complementary “purpose” test: the core action should reflect whether users grasp the product’s value.

quotes.topic_title: How Pinterest found its North Star metric
quotes.text: And so, we did this kind of top down, bottoms up analysis to make it very clear that when we launch an experiment or launch a new feature, if the probability, if the percentage of people that pin something doesn't go up, or the number of pins for that cohort doesn't go up, that experiment is not a a successful experiment.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Turns the North Star into an execution rule: experiments must move the core action metric to be considered successful.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube’s evolving core action: subscribing
quotes.text: Basically, what is most causal of retention as you're describing.
quotes.speaker: Lenny
quotes.context: Highlights a practical methodology: identify the activation milestone by analyzing what most causally drives retention.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube’s evolving core action: subscribing
quotes.text: "That's what it was in the early days, but we started to realize that it wasn't actually our core action. And we did a lot of analysis on YouTube and what we realized was that subscribing was the core action on YouTube."
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive example of a core action shifting from consumption (watching) to commitment (subscribing) based on analysis.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube’s evolving core action: subscribing
quotes.text: And so, the more people that subscribe to your content on YouTube, the more you have the accruing benefits and mounting loss of using YouTube.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Explains why subscribing creates compounding value and switching costs for creators—useful for designing durable engagement loops.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube’s evolving core action: subscribing
quotes.text: YouTube is a marketplace. You have the creators uploading content and the viewers who are watching it, supply and demand.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A memorable mental model reframing social products as two-sided marketplaces, guiding how to pick metrics and core actions.

quotes.topic_title: YouTube’s evolving core action: subscribing
quotes.text: you know you've got something really right with the core action when it's helping both sides of your network.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A clear criterion for validating a core action in networked products: it should create value for both supply and demand.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the engagement hierarchy to prioritization
quotes.text: Yeah, I think about consumer founders, product founders, product leaders in these companies that are thinking through the road map.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Clarifies the target audience for the framework—people responsible for setting and sequencing product priorities.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the engagement hierarchy to prioritization
quotes.text: What is the most important things that they need to prioritize, the big rocks, for the immediate short-term?
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Emphasizes using the framework to identify and focus on the highest-impact “big rocks” in the near-term roadmap.

quotes.topic_title: Applying the engagement hierarchy to prioritization
quotes.text: And the framework then provides a lens on what to prioritize.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Summarizes the practical value: a decision-making lens to guide prioritization rather than a list of tactics.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace hierarchy overview: beyond GMV vanity metrics
quotes.text: But if you focus, if the race that you think you're running is to grow MAUs or to grow GMV, you're not actually going to run the right race.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A warning that optimizing for top-line activity metrics can misdirect strategy away from building enduring value.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace hierarchy overview: beyond GMV vanity metrics
quotes.text: And actually, with marketplace, very interestingly, it can take you in the wrong direction.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Highlights the counterintuitive idea that GMV growth can actively push marketplace founders toward harmful decisions.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace hierarchy overview: beyond GMV vanity metrics
quotes.text: Right. And I think a lot of people started to feel like if you could hit $1,000,000 of annualized GMV, it means you're ready for your Series A. But it's kind of self-evident that not all GMV is created equal, right?
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Challenges the common fundraising milestone by emphasizing that GMV quality and concentration matter, not just the headline number.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace hierarchy overview: beyond GMV vanity metrics
quotes.text: And I would meet so many founders who would say, " Oh, well, I thought we had to prove out that the value proposition resonated in these other cities and so, that's why we're diffusing our focus." But what they what I would always feel is like they were just making their job so much harder by doing that.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Actionable advice to avoid spreading across geographies too early, since diffusion increases execution difficulty without proving durability.

quotes.topic_title: Marketplace hierarchy overview: beyond GMV vanity metrics
quotes.text: And getting to $1,000,000 of GMV in a constrained market is a lot harder, takes longer, but it's actually the path to building something that endures.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A durable-market-building heuristic: prioritize depth in a constrained market over faster GMV by “skimming the cream” in a huge one.

quotes.topic_title: Work backwards: dominate by tipping a market
quotes.text: Okay. There's probably a couple core insights, but the first one that I think about with this hierarchy is that when you're building a marketplace, you actually have to start from the goal and work backwards from there.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Introduces a practitioner-friendly methodology: define the marketplace endgame first, then derive the steps needed to reach it.

quotes.topic_title: Work backwards: dominate by tipping a market
quotes.text: You're basically building two companies at the same time, right? You have the product and go-to-market org for the demand side, the product and go-to-market org for the supply side.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for why marketplaces are uniquely hard: you must build and coordinate two full businesses simultaneously.

quotes.topic_title: Work backwards: dominate by tipping a market
quotes.text: And it kind of shows that the more dominant a marketplace is relative to the number two in its space, the more profitable that business is.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A concrete data-backed takeaway: profitability scales with dominance versus the #2 player, not just being “#1.”

quotes.topic_title: Work backwards: dominate by tipping a market
quotes.text: And so, it's just like a very clear like you don't want to be... Obviously, when you're building a marketplace, you don't want to be in the middle of the pack, but even being number one but just barely number one doesn't give you any of the benefits of a marketplace model, you're fighting for each incremental point of market share.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Counterintuitive warning that “barely #1” can still behave like a competitive slog, undermining marketplace advantages.

quotes.topic_title: Work backwards: dominate by tipping a market
quotes.text: And the only way to get to that place, to get to that moment of real dominance where you have this winner take most dynamic is that you have to tip your market, and that's the only scalable way to do that, and that's what level two is.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Defines the key mechanism in the hierarchy: tipping the market is the scalable path to durable, winner-take-most dominance.

quotes.topic_title: Level one focus: thimble strategy and happy GMV
quotes.text: I think that, really, what the the best, ambitious founders do is they focus that ambition like a laser beam on a small market, the thimble.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A memorable mental model for narrowing scope to win a constrained initial market before expanding.

quotes.topic_title: Level one focus: thimble strategy and happy GMV
quotes.text: And part of this is that we have to accept a couple of points of scarcity. One is that, you can't raise hundreds of millions of dollars from the start, where we, especially today, live in a world where there is a constraint around capital. And so, you have to be able to take that capital in the beginning and make the most out of it. And the only way to do that is to be very, very focused.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Actionable advice grounded in the practical constraints (capital) that force focus early in marketplace building.

quotes.topic_title: Level one focus: thimble strategy and happy GMV
quotes.text: And the second thing is that the constraint is the founder's attention. And again, these things are really, really difficult to to get off the ground, and the only way that you can do it is by having myopic focus on a segment.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: A counterweight to “go big fast” thinking: attention, not just money, is the binding constraint.

quotes.topic_title: Level one focus: thimble strategy and happy GMV
quotes.text: DoorDash on the other hand, famously and very controversially went after the suburbs in the beginning. And the beautiful thing about the suburbs is that there is very little competition because no one thought that you could do it economically.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Concrete example of choosing an overlooked wedge market to avoid competition and build retention.

quotes.topic_title: Level one focus: thimble strategy and happy GMV
quotes.text: And this word happy I use, I should expand on it a little bit because the realization I had as I reflected on this kind of feeling that GMV is really actually a vanity metric, it doesn't get at the core of whether you're building enduring value.
quotes.speaker: Sarah Tavel
quotes.context: Reframes marketplace success away from raw GMV toward customer-perceived value and retention.
